TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi serializable sealed beforefieldinit ImageListStreamer extends System.Object implements class System.IDisposable, class System.Runtime.Serialization.ISerializable

Docs.summary: Provides the data portion of an .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This is a sealed class, so you can not inherit from it. Also, the constructor is private, so you cannot create a new instance of it. An ImageListStreamer is returned by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageList.ImageStream%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageList>. However, you cannot use this class to load images to an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageList> control by directly assigning the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageList.ImageStream%2A> property from one <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageList>. Instead you should directly assign one <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageList> instance to another (for example, `ImageList2 = ImageList1)`.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Dispose() cil managed

Docs.summary: Releases all resources used by the current instance of the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Call `Dispose` when you are finished using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageListStreamer>. The `Dispose` method leaves the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageListStreamer> in an unusable state. After calling `Dispose`, you must release all references to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageListStreamer> so the garbage collector can reclaim the memory that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageListStreamer> was occupying.
For more information, see [Cleaning Up Unmanaged Resources](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md) and [Implementing a Dispose Method](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
> [!NOTE] > Always call `Dispose` before you release your last reference to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageListStreamer>. Otherwise, the resources it is using will not be freed until the garbage collector calls the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImageListStreamer> object's `Finalize` method.
